official-title.#text:
To amend title 49, United States Code, to establish an
		  Ombudsman Office within the Transportation Security Administration for the
		  purpose of enhancing transportation security by providing confidential,
		  informal, and neutral assistance to address work-place related problems of
		  Transportation Security Administration employees, and for other
		  purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Transportation Security Administration
			 Ombudsman Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following new section:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Subchapter II of chapter 449 of title 49, United States
			 Code

text.#text:
There
				is established an Office of the Ombudsman in the Transportation Security
				Administration.

on behalf of

labor and employment relations with Federal agencies; and

				resolution.

An

The appointment of

The reappointment
				as Ombudsman of an individual who is serving as Ombudsman.

The removal of
				an individual from the position of Ombudsman.

text.#text:
The
				Ombudsman shall—

employees, including publicizing a

text.#text:
conduct outreach
				to

evaluate each
				complainant’s claim objectively;

provide
				information, advice, and assistance to complainants and, as appropriate,
				initiate informal, impartial fact-finding and inquiries, on complaints or on
				the Ombudsman’s own initiative;

inform each
				complainant—

when the Ombudsman
				decides against conducting a fact-finding inquiry into the complaint;

on the status of
				the Ombudsman’s fact-finding inquiry to the complainant, on a regular basis if
				requested by the complainant; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to address issues
				identified through fact-finding and inquiries;

maintain
				confidential any matter related to complaints and inquiries, including the

text.#text:
submit an annual
				report to the appropriate congressional committees in accordance with

The Ombudsman shall report no later than September 30
				each year to the appropriate congressional committees on the actions taken by
				the Office of the Ombudsman over the preceding year and the objectives of those
				actions.

Each
				such report shall, for the period covered by the report, include—

statistical
				information, by region, on the volume of complaints received, general nature of
				complaints, general information on complainants, and the percentage of
				complaints that resulted in a fact-finding inquiry;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Administrator of
				the Transportation Security Administration
